column1: Foz do Iguaçu (Iguazu River Mouth) (Portuguese pronunciation: [ˈfɔz dw iɡwɐˈsu]) is the Brazilian city on the border of Iguaçu Falls. The city is the 7th largest in the state of Paraná. The city's population is approximately 258
column2: 000. It is approximately 650 km (400 mi) west of the capital of the state
column3: Curitiba
column4: being the westernmost city in that state.

column1: The inhabitants of the city are known as iguaçuenses. The Iguaçu Falls located on the border of Argentina and Brazil and consisting of approximately 257 individual waterfalls over 2.7 km (1.7 mi) were chosen as one of the "New Natural Seven Wonders of the World."The city is characterized by tourism and cultural diversity. There are about 80 nationalities
column2: being the most representative from Italy
column3: Portugal
column6: Paraguay and Argentina. Foz do Iguaçu is integrated into a tri-national region
column7: bordering the Argentine city of Puerto Iguazú and the Paraguayan city of Ciudad del Este. The city's economy is based on tourism
column8: with emphasis on trade and services.According to research conducted by the Brazilian Tourist Institute (Embratur) and the Foundation Institute of Economic Research (FIFE) in 2006
column10: Foz do Iguaçu was the 2nd most visited leisure destination by foreign tourists after Rio de Janeiro. In 2010
column11: it received from the Brazilian Ministry of Tourism 10 awards for Best Practices and Competitiveness Index. The Foz do Iguaçu Destination have been noted by various national and international media: the British newspaper The Guardian considered it is the best foreign destination for the UK. The U.S. TV network CNN classified it as one of the 14 most romantic destinations.Foz do Iguaçu is home of the Itaipu dam
column12: the world's second largest hydroelectric plant in power generation
column13: after the Three Gorges Dam in China. With 20 generator units and 14
column15: it provides approximately 15% of the energy consumed in Brazil and 86% of the energy consumed in Paraguay.

column1: The city has a low crime rate by Brazilian standards.
The climate of Foz do Iguaçu is humid subtropical
column2: with two distinctive seasons; one humid and hot in the summer and another
column3: dry and cold
column4: in the winter. The city's annual average temperature is 23.8 °C (74.8 °F)
column5: but can be as high as 40 °C (104 °F) in the summer (highest) or as low as -5 °C (23 °F) in the winter (lowest). The average in the summer is 26.5 °C (79.7 °F)and in the winter 15.4 °C (59.6 °F).

column1: The climate of the city is generally hot or warm throughout the year
column2: due to the relatively low altitude (standing only 173 m
the city is sunny during the year
column3: but rain is fairly common during the spring and in the summer. The weather of the city
column6: because the region where the city stands is the zone where frequently three fronts meet. As consequence
column7: it is not uncommon to see temperatures as high as 35 °C (95 °F) and in the summer as low as 8 °C (46 °F) in the city and frequent thunderstorms.

column2: a proposal was made to adjust the city name to Foz do Iguassu. The proposal was approved in a first debate and then rejected in a second debate
column3: at the Town Hall (Câmara Municipal)
column4: by four votes for and eight against. The bill was initiated by city councillor Djalma Pastorello
column5: of the PSDB.The purpose of the adjustment to the city name was to return the spelling to the original form
column6: as at the foundation of the city in 1914. The change occurred due language reforms of 1945
column7: which changed the orthography of Brazilian Portuguese. However
column8: existing proper names were not obliged to change. Another reason for the proposed adjustment back to the original was that 146 of the 198 member countries of the United Nations do not have the "ç" character in their alphabets.The adjustment would therefore rationalise any search for the city in search engines
column9: since Foz do Iguaçu's is more widely known for the falls
column10: which are known as the Iguassu Falls. Djalma Pastorello felt that tourism to the city of Foz do Iguaçu would be improved greatly by a clarification of its association with the now-famous Iguassu Falls. However
column11: he estimated that 70% of the city's population were against the name change because the local media anticipated the change and presented it in a distorted way
column12: so that locals were unable to see that the intention was to benefit the population.

column1: The residents are predominantly Roman Catholic but there is a relatively large minority of Muslims and Buddhists. The city has a large mosque and a Buddhist temple.
Fenartec is an annual event held in May to commemorate the city's multicultural diversity.

column1: The city does not operate its own municipal transport networks
column2: but instead licenses four private bus companies to operate services on its behalf. The bus fares are set by the municipality for all four companies. In 2003
column3: the city initiated an integrated city fare and created a hub near the city centre.

column2: most of the bus routes pass through this hub and passengers pay a standard fare within the city zone
column3: which enables them to transfer routes
column4: even when these may be operated by another company.

column1: The transport network extends to certain distant areas
column2: such as the city's airport and the Iguazu Park
column3: but not between the city and its neighbor Ciudad del Este
column5: which are serviced by other companies. These routes are not part of the integrated network
column6: a situation reflected by higher fares.
